title: Adding ProfilePlot and PhasePlot

content.raw: All tests pass. Good job!
content.html: All tests pass. Good job!

content.raw:
What do you think about using the `PlotMPL` class instead of `FigureContainer`? It lives in base_plot_types.py.  

Up to you about whether you want to refactor things here but it might be useful for getting the callbacks that make sense over here to work in the same way as they do for PlotWindow.
content.html:
What do you think about using the PlotMPL class instead of FigureContainer? It lives in base_plot_types.py.

Up to you about whether you want to refactor things here but it might be useful for getting the callbacks that make sense over here to work in the same way as they do for PlotWindow.

content.raw:
This is really awesome.  Thanks for taking the time to do this.

I like the new `ProfilePlot` API and have no substantive comments about the design. My only suggestion is that you should implement `_repr_html_`.  This function is used by a hook in IPython to enable inline display of plots in the notebook whenever an object's `__repr__` method is invoked.  For this reason it's also useful to return `self` from class member functions that modify plots.  This way the modified plot is displayed inline in the notebook immediately after modifying the plot.  Take a look at plot_window.py for some concrete examples or please contact me if you have any questions about this.  It's really important this gets added since it significantly improves usability from within the notebook.

My other comment is that `ProfilePlot` needs tests. This could be in the form of unit tests (creating `ProfilePlot`s using fake in-memory data) , answer tests (a `ProfilePlot` created using real data and directly compared with a previously generated gold standard), or both.  The former is useful to make sure there aren't any crashing bugs and to make sure we can save plots using all allowed formats.  The latter is useful to make sure answers don't change with time. Take a look at test_plot_window.py in yt/visualization/tests.

Thanks again.  Let me know if you have any questions about anything I've suggested.
content.html:
This is really awesome. Thanks for taking the time to do this.

I like the new ProfilePlot API and have no substantive comments about the design. My only suggestion is that you should implement _repr_html_. This function is used by a hook in IPython to enable inline display of plots in the notebook whenever an object's __repr__ method is invoked. For this reason it's also useful to return self from class member functions that modify plots. This way the modified plot is displayed inline in the notebook immediately after modifying the plot. Take a look at plot_window.py for some concrete examples or please contact me if you have any questions about this. It's really important this gets added since it significantly improves usability from within the notebook.

My other comment is that ProfilePlot needs tests. This could be in the form of unit tests (creating ProfilePlots using fake in-memory data) , answer tests (a ProfilePlot created using real data and directly compared with a previously generated gold standard), or both. The former is useful to make sure there aren't any crashing bugs and to make sure we can save plots using all allowed formats. The latter is useful to make sure answers don't change with time. Take a look at test_plot_window.py in yt/visualization/tests.

Thanks again. Let me know if you have any questions about anything I've suggested.

content.raw:
Hi @ngoldbaum I like having the `__repr__` method, too.  Would it be okay if we delayed on that, until after the `PhasePlot` setup has been implemented?

As for the tests, `ProfilePlot` itself does not have them, *but*, the new profile objects do.  I would be fine implementing the tests for the plotting functions, so I'll take that on.
content.html:
Hi Nathan Goldbaum I like having the __repr__ method, too. Would it be okay if we delayed on that, until after the PhasePlot setup has been implemented?

As for the tests, ProfilePlot itself does not have them, but, the new profile objects do. I would be fine implementing the tests for the plotting functions, so I'll take that on.

If it will happen before the 2.6 release I don't think it matters when it gets included, but it needs to happen by then.

content.raw: @ngoldbaum I've looked this over in the course of refactoring, and I think I am going to punt on it for now.  I think it would work, but it's not clear to me yet that it provides a lot of benefit without adding a lot to the API -- for instance, figure size and so on.  So I would like to say we'll do this, but not now.
content.html: Nathan Goldbaum I've looked this over in the course of refactoring, and I think I am going to punt on it for now. I think it would work, but it's not clear to me yet that it provides a lot of benefit without adding a lot to the API -- for instance, figure size and so on. So I would like to say we'll do this, but not now.

content.raw: I think subclassing PWViewerMPL means that callbacks are added to the plot.  This is great (and it would be nice if we could do the same for `ProfilePlot`) but to make sure everything is self-consistent I think you'll need to edit `setup_callbacks` (line 750 of `plot_window.py`) to disable the callbacks that don't make any sense for this plot type.
content.html: I think subclassing PWViewerMPL means that callbacks are added to the plot. This is great (and it would be nice if we could do the same for ProfilePlot) but to make sure everything is self-consistent I think you'll need to edit setup_callbacks (line 750 of plot_window.py) to disable the callbacks that don't make any sense for this plot type.

content.raw:
Now that I think about it, it may not be a good idea to subclass PWViewerMPL at all.  Right now PhasePlot has the following attributes:


```
#!python


plot.bounds
plot.save
plot.set_window_size
plot.display
plot.set_antialias
plot.set_zlim
plot.fields
plot.set_axes_unit
plot.setup_callbacks
plot.get_log
plot.set_buff_size
plot.show
plot.pan
plot.set_center
plot.width
plot.pan_rel 
plot.set_cmap
plot.x_log
plot.piter
plot.set_font
plot.x_title
plot.plot_title
plot.set_log
plot.y_log
plot.plots
plot.set_title
plot.y_title
plot.profile
plot.set_transform
plot.z_log
plot.refresh
plot.set_width
plot.z_title
plot.run_callbacks
plot.set_window
plot.zoom

```

I think about half of these don't make any sense in the context of a phase plot.  `set_width`, `zoom`, `pan`, `set_window_size`, `set_center`...

A few of these do make sense but I don't think will work correctly since they're not overridden inside `PhasePlot`'s definition.  `set_axes_unit`, and `set_zlim` jump out at me.

I see now that the callbacks actually aren't attached to the instance, so my comment above is actually invalid.  Sorry for the noise about that :/

Rather than subclassing `PWViewerMPL`, perhaps we should refactor the functionality you want into a new class that `PhasePlot`, `PWViewerMPL` and `ProfilePlot` can subclass.  This way `ProfilePlot` should have the roughly the same inheritance tree as well. Let me know if you want to chat in a lower-latency fashion about this.  I think it would be a straightforward refactor and I'd be happy to help out with it.

I see now that the callbacks actually aren't attached to the instance, so my comment above is actually invalid. Sorry for the noise about that :/

Rather than subclassing PWViewerMPL, perhaps we should refactor the functionality you want into a new class that PhasePlot, PWViewerMPL and ProfilePlot can subclass. content.raw:
Look on the bright side.  About half of those *are* relevant!  Just kidding.

I did my best to make the relevant modifiers actually work.  This is includes ``set_cmap``, ``set_zlim``, and I think ``set_font`` as well.  The ones that shouldn't be there or don't work are the following: 

* ``plot.bounds``

* ``plot.set_window_size``

* ``plot.set_antialias`` (not sure)

* ``plot.fields``

* ``plot.set_axes_unit``

* ``plot.setup_callbacks`` (maybe that should be there, but callbacks aren't configured right yet)

* ``plot.get_log``

* ``plot.set_buffer_size``

* ``plot.pan``

* ``plot.set_center``

* ``plot.width``

* ``plot.pan_rel``

* ``plot.piter`` (not sure why that's here)

* ``plot.set_transform``

* ``plot.refresh`` (probably should be added, but didn't do anything with it)

* ``plot.set_width``

* ``plot.run_callbacks``

* ``plot.set_window``

* ``plot.zoom``

I am supportive of a refactor of the plot and viewer classes, but I personally do not have the time or energy to do this in the near future.  @ngoldbaum if you'd like to take a crack at this (and you're probably the best person to do so), please feel free.  I am about 60% done with the narrative docs and cookbook recipes for ``ProfilePlot`` and ``PhasePlot`` and I will likely be able to finish them this evening.  Perhaps, for now, this PR can be vetted and accepted based on core functionality and the refactor can take place with this in the codebase for people to use and for me to finish up the documentation in parallel.  Would that be ok?

Perhaps, for now, this PR can be vetted and accepted based on core functionality and the refactor can take place with this in the codebase for people to use and for me to finish up the documentation in parallel. Would that be ok?

content.raw:
Hi @brittonsmith . So I just pulled this in and am testing it out because I wanted to use it for some radial profiles. It fails with

```
#!python


---------------------------------------------------------------------------
ValueError                                Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-13-7d4325a2d66a> in <module>()
      1 sphere = pf.h.sphere(den_c, (2., "mpchcm"))
      2 plot = ProfilePlot(sphere, "RadiusMpc", ["Density"],
----> 3                    weight_field="CellMassMsun")

/afs/slac.stanford.edu/u/ki/skillman/local/src/yt-hg/yt/visualization/profile_plotter.py in __init__(self, data_source, x_field, y_fields, weight_field, n_bins, accumulation, label, plot_spec, profiles)
    206             self.plot_spec = [self.plot_spec.copy() for p in self.profiles]
    207 
--> 208         self._setup_plots()
    209 
    210     def save(self, name=None):

/afs/slac.stanford.edu/u/ki/skillman/local/src/yt-hg/yt/visualization/profile_plotter.py in _setup_plots(self)
    303             xscale, yscale = self._get_field_log(fname, profile)
    304             xtitle, ytitle = self._get_field_title(fname, profile)
--> 305             axes.set_xscale(xscale)
    306             axes.set_yscale(yscale)
    307             axes.set_xlabel(xtitle)

/u/ki/skillman/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/matplotlib-1.3.0-py2.7-linux-x86_64.egg/matplotlib/axes.pyc in set_xscale(self, value, **kwargs)
   2575         """
   2576         self.xaxis._set_scale(value, **kwargs)
-> 2577         self.autoscale_view(scaley=False)
   2578         self._update_transScale()
   2579 

/u/ki/skillman/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/matplotlib-1.3.0-py2.7-linux-x86_64.egg/matplotlib/axes.pyc in autoscale_view(self, tight, scalex, scaley)
   1942                 x1 += delta
   1943             if not _tight:
-> 1944                 x0, x1 = xlocator.view_limits(x0, x1)
   1945             self.set_xbound(x0, x1)
   1946 

/u/ki/skillman/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/matplotlib-1.3.0-py2.7-linux-x86_64.egg/matplotlib/ticker.pyc in view_limits(self, vmin, vmax)
   1483         if minpos <= 0 or not np.isfinite(minpos):
   1484             raise ValueError(
-> 1485                 "Data has no positive values, and therefore can not be "
   1486                 "log-scaled.")
   1487 

ValueError: Data has no positive values, and therefore can not be log-scaled.
```

I think it is because RadiusMpc (the x-field) goes to zero. Since I would think radial profiles will be one of the most often-used cases for this, I think we should handle this a bit better.  I'm not sure what the best way is yet, since I know we don't want to clutter up the constructor for the ProfilePlot class, but robustly determining a minimum log-scale value for things like radius might be really tricky... Would you be completely opposed to a bounds kwarg?  Same thing goes for create_profile.

I think it is because RadiusMpc (the x-field) goes to zero. Since I would think radial profiles will be one of the most often-used cases for this, I think we should handle this a bit better. I'm not sure what the best way is yet, since I know we don't want to clutter up the constructor for the ProfilePlot class, but robustly determining a minimum log-scale value for things like radius might be really tricky... Would you be completely opposed to a bounds kwarg? Same thing goes for create_profile.

content.raw:
@samskillman, are you sure there isn't some other problem with the profile that was created?  Matplotlib should be able to handle a log plot that has a zero in it, but it looks to me like all of your profile data is zero.  Can you check the profile data by looking at ``plot.profiles``?

That said, I would be ok with adding a range keyword since I think that would be useful anyway.  Anyone else have thoughts on a range or bounds kwarg?
content.html:
Sam Skillman, are you sure there isn't some other problem with the profile that was created? Matplotlib should be able to handle a log plot that has a zero in it, but it looks to me like all of your profile data is zero. Can you check the profile data by looking at plot.profiles?

That said, I would be ok with adding a range keyword since I think that would be useful anyway. Anyone else have thoughts on a range or bounds kwarg?

content.raw: Won't this repeatedly cumsum() the profile data if plot is called on a profile multiple times?  I don't think we should be modifying the profile data when plotting.
content.html: Won't this repeatedly cumsum() the profile data if plot is called on a profile multiple times? I don't think we should be modifying the profile data when plotting.

content.raw: Rather than adding new keywords, our strategy with `PlotWindow` has been to add setter functions.  What do you think about adding `set_xrange` and `set_yrange`?
content.html: Rather than adding new keywords, our strategy with PlotWindow has been to add setter functions. What do you think about adding set_xrange and set_yrange?

content.raw: The profiles all have valid data, though I have to manually create a Profile1D to check. Upon looking closer, I think this is a matplotlib bug, or at least a bad error check.  The minpos = 0, which is raising this error.  In fact, the data does have many positive values...
content.html: The profiles all have valid data, though I have to manually create a Profile1D to check. Upon looking closer, I think this is a matplotlib bug, or at least a bad error check. The minpos = 0, which is raising this error. In fact, the data does have many positive values...

content.raw: Won't be enough if it just straight up errors and doesn't return a valid plot to modify.  Also, I think the profile might have to know the bounds when it is being made, especially when radius might vary from 1.0e-2 to 1.0, but have valid radii down to 1.0e-10. Would end up wasting a lot of bins.
content.html: Won't be enough if it just straight up errors and doesn't return a valid plot to modify. Also, I think the profile might have to know the bounds when it is being made, especially when radius might vary from 1.0e-2 to 1.0, but have valid radii down to 1.0e-10. Would end up wasting a lot of bins.

content.raw: Good point, plus we already have bounds keywords for `PlotCollection` plots.  No reason to make these new plot types less versatile.
content.html: Good point, plus we already have bounds keywords for PlotCollection plots. No reason to make these new plot types less versatile.

content.raw: If it's a logged field, we can/should specify `non_zero` as True to the Quantity object.  These plots won't be less versatile, but I would very, very much like to keep the absolute simplest calls as simple as possible.  It's not hard to make new profile objects anymore.
content.html: If it's a logged field, we can/should specify non_zero as True to the Quantity object. These plots won't be less versatile, but I would very, very much like to keep the absolute simplest calls as simple as possible. It's not hard to make new profile objects anymore.

I think we can get around this if we choose the extrema based on non-zero values if the field is logged. This is done in the plot collection like this (non_zero=x_log):

        if x_bounds is None:
            x_min, x_max = data_source.quantities["Extrema"](
                            fields[0], non_zero = x_log,
                            lazy_reader=lazy_reader)[0]
        else:
            x_min, x_max = x_bounds

content.raw:
In order to handle log fields, I think this needs to be something like:

```
#!python
logs = [data_source.pf.field_info[f].take_log for f in bin_fields]
ex = data_source.quantities["Extrema"](bin_fields, non_zero = np.any(logs))
```

I'm not sure how to handle mixing of log/linear bin fields here, or if we should care too much...
content.html:
In order to handle log fields, I think this needs to be something like:

logs = [data_source.pf.field_info[f].take_log for f in bin_fields]
ex = data_source.quantities["Extrema"](bin_fields, non_zero = np.any(logs))

I'm not sure how to handle mixing of log/linear bin fields here, or if we should care too much...

content.raw: Good catch, @samskillman.  I put the option in the plotter because I didn't want to clutter up ``create_profile``.  I now think the best option is just to remove the accumulation kwarg altogether and mandate that this be done by hand by the user.  What do you think about that?  If that's ok, I'll update the docs and recipes to reflect this.  It might end up being more empowering for the user to realize that they can do this on their own without having to rely on additional keyword args.
content.html: Good catch, Sam Skillman. I put the option in the plotter because I didn't want to clutter up create_profile. I now think the best option is just to remove the accumulation kwarg altogether and mandate that this be done by hand by the user. What do you think about that? If that's ok, I'll update the docs and recipes to reflect this. It might end up being more empowering for the user to realize that they can do this on their own without having to rely on additional keyword args.

content.raw:
Actually, I think this might come up fairly often (thanks a lot radial velocity profile!).  I just changed it to:

```
#!python

ex = [data_source.quantities["Extrema"](f, non_zero=l)[0] \
          for f, l in zip(bin_fields, logs)]
```

What do you think of that?
content.html:
Actually, I think this might come up fairly often (thanks a lot radial velocity profile!). I just changed it to:

ex = [data_source.quantities["Extrema"](f, non_zero=l)[0] \
          for f, l in zip(bin_fields, logs)]

What do you think of that?

content.raw: All tests pass. Good job!
content.html: All tests pass. Good job!

content.raw:
This definitely works, but will require multiple passes over the data. I
think it's the right way for now, but if we extend the non-zero keyword to
take a sequence we can reduce it. So I'm on board with this!
content.html: This definitely works, but will require multiple passes over the data. I think it's the right way for now, but if we extend the non-zero keyword to take a sequence we can reduce it. So I'm on board with this!

content.raw:
Cool.  I think altering the Extrema quantity is definitely a better
solution looking forward.  I didn't want to change the working of core
machinery so late in the game, but I think that's probably what we should
do in yt-3.0.
content.html: Cool. I think altering the Extrema quantity is definitely a better solution looking forward. I didn't want to change the working of core machinery so late in the game, but I think that's probably what we should do in yt-3.0.

content.raw:
Hey Britton,

I think the accumulation keyword is useful enough that we should leave it in.  Just my $.02.
content.html:
Hey Britton,

I think the accumulation keyword is useful enough that we should leave it in. Just my $.02.

content.raw: Yeah, this is tricky. It'd be nice if when the actual plotting was done the accumulation was done.  That way in principle it could even modify the label to add something like (< xfield). Of course, some people may want to do ( > xfield), so in general I'm not sure how we should handle it. I think we could do accumulation = [0], -1, or 1 ?? I don't know.
content.html: Yeah, this is tricky. It'd be nice if when the actual plotting was done the accumulation was done. That way in principle it could even modify the label to add something like (< xfield). Of course, some people may want to do ( > xfield), so in general I'm not sure how we should handle it. I think we could do accumulation = [0], -1, or 1 ?? I don't know.

content.raw: Actually, on second thought, let's disable it for now and then come back to this later.
content.html: Actually, on second thought, let's disable it for now and then come back to this later.

content.raw: I'm okay with that for now.
content.html: I'm okay with that for now.

content.raw: Other than the tests (which DO exist for the profile objects, but not for the profile PLOTS), is there any reason not to accept this at this point?  If not, I will do so, and add tests in a subsequent PR.
content.html: Other than the tests (which DO exist for the profile objects, but not for the profile PLOTS), is there any reason not to accept this at this point? If not, I will do so, and add tests in a subsequent PR.

content.raw: Yeah, the accumulation needs to be disabled for now.
content.html: Yeah, the accumulation needs to be disabled for now.

content.raw: I am fixing up some issues related to the comments on accumulation.  I should be updating the PR shortly in a way that should satisfy everyone.
content.html: I am fixing up some issues related to the comments on accumulation. I should be updating the PR shortly in a way that should satisfy everyone.

content.raw: Instead of disabling the functionality, I went ahead and moved it to create_profile and made it support multidimensional accumulation.  While I was at it, I decided to bring back fractional as well since it was trivial and now makes the ``create_profile`` function basically complete.  Let me know what you think of this.
content.html: Instead of disabling the functionality, I went ahead and moved it to create_profile and made it support multidimensional accumulation. While I was at it, I decided to bring back fractional as well since it was trivial and now makes the create_profile function basically complete. Let me know what you think of this.

content.raw: All tests pass. Good job!
content.html: All tests pass. Good job!

content.raw: All tests pass. Good job!
content.html: All tests pass. Good job!

content.raw: Okay, this looks great.  I was the last holdout, so, I'm accepting!  Thanks Britton and everyone else.  This is awesome.
content.html: Okay, this looks great. I was the last holdout, so, I'm accepting! Thanks Britton and everyone else. This is awesome.

description:
This PR contains a rewrite of profiles by Matt, including a new create_profile function to easily create profiles of 1, 2, and 3D.  This also brings the addition of a new ProfilePlot command to create quick plots of 1D profiles from either a single dataset, or overplot from multiple datasets using a time series.  A 2D profile analog will be coming later in the form of PhasePlot, but that is not ready yet.

Here is an example of use with a single dataset:

http://paste.yt-project.org/show/3975/

With multiple datasets, using the from_profiles class method:

http://paste.yt-project.org/show/3976/

This one also shows the use of the `set_line_property` command, which can be used to set plot properties for one or all of the plotted lines.

Cookbook recipes have been added and a PR will be issued for those shortly.  I have not added narrative docs yet, as I'd like to wait until PhasePlot is finished and then I can remove the whole discussion of using the PlotCollection all at once.  Note, this does not support interactive plotting with a `show` command just yet, either.

Matt, please have a look at the final commit of this PR, which contains a fix to a problem that was occurring when trying to run the first of the two example scripts I pasted.  Basically, the top grid was included in the list of grids for the sphere, but all of the points were covered by more refined points, so when it went to calculate the number of points in that grid it came back with None.  If fixed this by simply checking the return before moving on, but maybe this needs to be fixed higher up the line during detection of which grids should belong in the sphere's list of grids.

Update 1: Matt has added _repr_html for ProfilePlot and I have added PhasePlot.

PhasePlot example script here: 

http://paste.yt-project.org/show/4045/

PhasePlot reuses a bunch of ProfilePlot functionality and may need a little additional cleanup, but if everything is functional, I think it may be worth it to accept sooner and clean up later.  I will now add narrative docs for these and @MatthewTurk has volunteered to take care of the tests.

Also, it looks like we have a merger conflict.  I'll try to take care of that soon.

Update 2: fixed merger conflicts and added PhasePlot to yt.mods.

Update 3: adding ability for "simulation" convenience function to check test_data_dir and adding accumulation keyword for from_profiles class method.

Update 4: @MatthewTurk has fixed Issue #722, so things like radial profiles now work with this functionality.  Thanks, Matt!

Update 5: @ngoldbaum has courageously refactored the plot containers to useful for both the ``PlotWindow`` and ``PhasePlot``.  As soon as we get some tests, I think we'll be ready to go.

Update 6: pushed a fix to get extrema separately for log and linear fields.  @samskillman, does this fix the issue?

Update 7: I have added accumulation and fractional kwargs to create_profile so that ProfilePlot and PhasePlot can both use them.  This way, the user has access to this functionality, but it is all performed within create_profile to keep the plotters clean.

Update 8: Added accumulation and fraction attributes to the profile objects created with create_profile so that this information is not lost and can be used later for things like altering plot labels.
